content.description: Sit start matched on big obvious edge, traverse and ascend the crimpy face to top out above the boulder's left arete.  Fun but make sure you have fresh skin for this one.
content.location: Far right side of the front face of the Right Split Boulder.

content.description: Awesome slabby warmup.  Don't worry about the moss, everything you need is free and clear.  That being said the aesthetics of this problem could probably be improved with a brush.  Stand start on the big foot rail using whatever works for your hands.  move up the delicate slab and top it out.
content.location: on the inside face of the right split boulder.

content.description: Stand Start using the seam at head height, mantle the boulder.
Tricky, balancy little mantle on the side of the left Split boulder. Sit start on righ facing sidepull jugrail for your right hand and high good crimp for your left.  Mantle it out.
content.protection: you don't need any, just watch your shin should your foot blow.  And by watch, i mean watch as it bounces off the rock.

content.description: Start with left hand on arete and right hand on a crimp. Climb up following the arete to top out. Balancy start to easier finish. Kinda techy fun problem.
content.location: Split boulders - Left boulder - on the right hand side. Located to the right of banana split.

content.description: Stand Start using the arete and an undercling, dyno/deadpoint to a good edge then top out.
content.protection: 1-2 pads, spotter to keep you out of the tree.

content.description:
There are a couple variations to this thing, and the V6 version of the problem is probably the most contrived of the bunch.  That being said, it's really, really good.  To do it the hard way, start on the far right hand side of the creekside boulder and traverse left staying low on the boulder and aiming for a prominent gaston crimp and sloper then mantle it out.   

  For an easier line that probably checks in around V3, instead of traversing low and left go up diagonally from the start, using the handholds of the harder variation as feet.  The moves on this are nowhere near as fun as the harder version.
content.location: Creekside Boulder.  Just off the main trail to the left

content.description: Start low in the middle of the creekside boulder and throw for the lip.  An awesome video on this problem can be seen in Kevin Catlin's GS Beta Series onchetroy.com
Sit start w/ sidepull & arete. Crux is in the middle topout is friendly
content.location:
This boulder sits below the mushroom boulders & is on the trail.  

  Walk off back of boulder.

content.description: Cool little trailside area that houses a suprising amount of high quality problems considering the amount of rock present.  The Creekside boulder has the real gems, but the stuff on the split boulders aint bad either.
